awd_titl_txt: Language emergence in the manual modality
awd_abstract_narration:
Disentangling contributions to language structure that are driven by learners from contributions that are driven by the way language is used is difficult in typical language-learning circumstances. This research program turns to individuals in an unusual language-learning situation--deaf individuals who are developing a manual communication system in the absence of input from a conventional language--to address this question, and then complements the fieldwork with an experimental study in the lab. The goal of the project is to assess the degree to which linguistic structures can develop in a manual communication system when it is--and is not--shared with others. In addition to its theoretical importance in exploring properties of language that are so resilient they need not be learned from a language model, the research program has practical significance. Informed of the capacities that children bring with them to language learning, educators may be better able to help deaf children or hearing children with language disabilities learn a conventional language, signed or spoken. Moreover, discovering how linguistic properties continue to grow and become structured in the lab studies has the potential to provide insight into conditions that promote the development of these properties in children with disabilities.

The specific aims of this project are to determine which linguistic features are resilient to the absence of linguistic input, which emerge only in the process of dyadic communication, and which emerge only via transmission to a new generation of learners. Homesigners are deaf individuals whose hearing losses prevent them from learning a spoken language, and whose hearing families have not exposed them to a conventional sign language. Despite their lack of input from a conventional language, homesigners communicate and use gestures that have many of the properties of natural language to do so.  In the first study, homesigners from Guatemala who do, or do not, regularly interact with other homesigners will be observed to determine the impact that sharing a communication system has on the emergence of linguistic structure. In the second study, hearing adults will be asked to describe scenes not by speaking, but by using their hands, in the laboratory under three conditions:  on their own; in collaboration with another gesturer; or after learning the gestures from another gesturer. This gesture-creation paradigm is designed to mirror the naturalistic situations in which homesigns are found:  homesigns created in an environment where there are no other homesigners; homesigns created by homesigners in the presence of other homesigners; and homesigns transmitted to a new generation of learners.

por.por_cntn:
Not all word orders are created equal. Although the order of Subjects, Objects, and Verbs across the world's languages can, in principle, be combined in six different ways, the vast majority of the world's signed and spoken languages tend to be either SOV or SVO (Dryer, 2013b; Greenberg, 1963; Napoli & Sutton-Spence, 2014). Likewise, although the order of nouns and their adjectives can be either pre-nominal (AdjNoun, "the orange cat") or post-nominal (NounAdj, "the cat orange"), the majority of the world's languages (approximately 64%), signed and spoken, exhibit the NounAdj order (Coons, 2022; Dryer, 2013a; Greenberg, 1963). 

Given the many ways in which languages can, and do, differ, robust, cross- linguistic patterns like the tendency towards SOV and SVO in the Verb Phrase and NounAdj in the Noun Phrase represent an important area of investigation because they raise important questions for work at the intersection of theoretical, experimental, and typological linguistics. Understanding the roots of these cross-linguistic patterns, for example, may provide insight into the factors that give rise to and shape linguistic systems. The overarching goal of our work is, therefore, to understand why some word-ordering patterns are more typologically common than others. 

In our past work, we have investigated the relative ordering of Objects and Verbs in the Verb Phrase and have found that there is a cognitive bias for using the SOV word order to describe events involving one animate entity acting on another entity (e.g., a girl kicking a ball). In the current project, we asked (i) whether the typological prominence for the NounAdj order could also be attributed to a cognitive bias for ordering Nouns before Adjective modifiers.
We tested this in two ways: first, among deaf signers of Nicaraguan Sign Language (NSL), a still-emerging language, so that we could see what word ordering conventions are used by individual inventing a language without input from or exposure to another language model; and second, in the lab with silent gesturers, hearing individuals who are asked to silently describe events using only their hands, so that we can see what word orders individuals use when they're deprived of access to their (spoken) language models.

We replicated our findings in the Verb Phrase, finding a bias towards the SOV word order among NSL signers and among silent gestures. We also found that NSL signers and silent gesturers preferred the NounAdj order, pointing to deep human biases in the structures underpinning and constituting word order in human language. Interestingly, though, we also found some differences in the strength of the bias towards the NounAdj versus the SOV word orders, laying the groundwork for our future investigations.
 
In sum, our project so far suggests that one reason certain word orders (SOV, NounAdj) are robustly represented across the world's languages may be the cognitive biases individuals (NSL signers and hearing gestures) bring = to language creation. But how then do we account for other word orders, SVO and AdjNoun, which are well represented in the world's languages, but less frequent in NSL and silent gesture? And, how do we account for the fact that, while it might be possible for languages to have variable word orders, they largely develop a single, consistent word ordering pattern? This is the question that we intend to pursue in our ongoing and future work.
